title: Presidential Election Chances, Practice Run
description: See how different probabilities lead to different outcomes with an interactive chart.Tags: election, probability
author: Nathan Yau
excerpt: See how different probabilities lead to different outcomes with an interactive chart.
text: By now you’ve seen or chosen to ignore forecasts that provide probabilities for a presidential candidate winning the election. Run enough elections with a given probability and the results converge. On the other hand, individual outcomes are a lot less certain. The interactive chart below lets you test the chances for Kamala Harris and Donald Trump winning the electoral college. Adjust the chances and see the possible outcomes. Pro tip: Hold down the button for repeated elections. It’s tempting to see a candidate with higher chances than another and feel like the results are mostly decided. But as of today and most of this cycle, the election is basically a toss-up. The moral of the story is to vote, regardless of the forecasts. Made possible by FlowingData members, since 2012. Support an independent site. Make great charts. See What You GetFlowingData is supported by paid memberships. If you liked this (or want to make similar data things), please consider supporting this small corner of the internet with a membership. Thanks. — Nathan, a real person
html:
By now you’ve seen or chosen to ignore forecasts that provide probabilities for a presidential candidate winning the election. Run enough elections with a given probability and the results converge. On the other hand, individual outcomes are a lot less certain.

The interactive chart below lets you test the chances for Kamala Harris and Donald Trump winning the electoral college.

Adjust the chances and see the possible outcomes.

Pro tip: Hold down the button for repeated elections.

It’s tempting to see a candidate with higher chances than another and feel like the results are mostly decided. But as of today and most of this cycle, the election is basically a toss-up.

The moral of the story is to vote, regardless of the forecasts.
